notes written one Sunday on the French countryside

Evolution of communal life, sort of describing parts of the process do demotion/transformation of the mysterious, but also subtly linking it to what was discussed on the previous chapter.

A quasi idyllic description of peasant life in Europe before and during the Middle Ages, focusing on the communal aspects.

Festivals served the purpose of tightening social links, as well as partaking on the mysterious; trying to find/maintain order in the chaos of nature, almost mimicking it in a sense, with lavish expenses after mons of hard work - the future would always carry uncertainty and the resources used in a festival could be better used on a famine/drought.

The gathering of communal resources also gave way to some donating more than others and being more blessed/being given more political power because of that. The communal equilibrium is thus altered and slowly promotes a ruling caste of those most blessed. It's a bit of an oversimplification, but that process takes us to current times where the mysterious is no more name rituals have lost their meaning, but are in a sense still carried and respected, at the same time the ruling class is now completely formed and crystallised.
